channel.title: Posts on Hasan Faraz Khan
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Hasan Faraz Khan

item.title: Embracing Learning: My Journey into Backend and System Design
item.description:
Embracing Learning: My Journey into Backend and System Design Link to heading

Welcome to my blog! I’m excited to share that I’ll be documenting my learning experiences in backend development and system design. This isn’t just a platform to showcase my skills or brag about my accomplishments; rather, it’s a valuable tool for my own revision and deepening my understanding of complex concepts.

As I set out on this path, I’ve come to understand that documenting my learning aids in knowledge retention. It forces me to go back over subjects, make sense of what I’m thinking, and investigate places I might not have seen at first. Every blog entry will function as a contemplative activity, enabling me to amalgamate my acquired knowledge and disseminate it to individuals who could profit from my perspectives.

item.title: Google Summer of Code 2021 | End of Phase-1 | Hydra Ecosystem
GSoC 2021 | Week 1–2 — Coding Period @ Hydra Ecosystem
Google Summer of Code 2021 — Community Bonding Period @ Hydra Ecosystem
item.description:
Finally GSoC’21 community bonding period is over and now we’ll be moving to the coding phase. It was an amazing journey for me. I made some contributions to the projects and learned a lot of things from my mentors. In this blog, I’ll be sharing my journey with Hydra Ecosystem as an open-source contributor.

I started my journey of open-source contributions with Hydra Ecosystem. Hydra Ecosystem aims to build a set of tools to automate the process of building REST APIs and Next-Gen smart clients which follow the principle of Semantic Web, Linked Data, and JSON-LD. Hydra is a vocabulary for APIs which machines can understand and it is currently a draft that is created and maintained by Hydra-CG. Check Specifications.

item.title: Using Signals in Django framework. How do they work ?
item.description: The Django Signals can be used to get notified when certain events occur. They can also be used for database logging. Let’s say you want to perform some logic every time a given model instance is updated, but there are several places in your codebase that this model can be updated. You can do that using signals, hooking some pieces of code to be executed every time this specific model’s save method is triggered.
